title: George Pataki’s Plan to Aid Israel With Bomb Marks Big Change
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003917367" crop="592" type="image"]

George E. Pataki's suggestion that the United States give Israel the Massive Ordnance Penetrator would mark a huge change: The United States has never given that bomb, or the B-2 needed to drop it, to any ally, and it would remove from American control how and when to respond to Iran.
content_expanded: George E. Pataki’s suggestion that the United States give Israel the Massive Ordnance Penetrator would mark a huge change: The United States has never given that bomb, or the B-2 needed to drop it, to any ally, and it would remove from American control how and when to respond to Iran.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Clash Over Kim Davis, the Kentucky Clerk
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003917302" crop="592" type="video" autostart="false"]

The Supreme Court's ruling on gay marriage instantly created a new and potent issue about religious liberty for the 2016 presidential campaign, and it is splitting the Republican Party. One side cheers on a Kentucky clerk who has refused to issue marriage licenses to gay couples, and the other side argues that officials must enforce the law.

<!-- more -->

That divide over religious freedom played out forcefully in the "undercard" debate on Wednesday night as George E. Pataki, the former governor of New York, clashed with Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator. Mr. Pataki said he would have fired Kim Davis, the clerk in Kentucky, while Mr. Santorum held her up as a hero for standing against a  "judge's unconstitutional" ruling. "How many clerks are we going to throw in jail?" Mr. Santorum asked.

That prompted a back-and-forth between the two men, with Mr. Pataki offering a "wow" before asking whether Mr. Santorum would support a president who didn't follow the law. Mr. Santorum interrupted, and the two talked over each other. 

The clerk has continued to insist she will not marry gay couples, even as she allows her deputies to do so. The issue appears not to be going away in Kentucky, or in the presidential campaign.
content_expanded:
Photo: Max Whittaker for The New York Times; Video: By CNN

One side cheers on a Kentucky clerk who has refused to issue marriage licenses to gay couples, and the other side argues that officials must enforce the law.

Pataki, the former governor of New York, clashed with Rick Santorum, the former Pennsylvania senator. Mr. Pataki said he would have fired Kim Davis, the clerk in Kentucky, while Mr. Santorum held her up as a hero for standing against a “judge’s unconstitutional” ruling. “How many clerks are we going to throw in jail?” Mr. Santorum asked.

That prompted a back-and-forth between the two men, with Mr. Pataki offering a “wow” before asking whether Mr. Santorum would support a president who didn’t follow the law. Mr. Santorum interrupted, and the two talked over each other.

The clerk has continued to insist she will not marry gay couples, even as she allows her deputies to do so. The issue appears not to be going away in Kentucky, or in the presidential campaign.

title: Bobby Jindal on Religious Liberty
content:
America did not create religious liberty; religious liberty created the United States of America. It is the reason we are here today.
— Bobby Jindal
content_expanded:
America did not create religious liberty; religious liberty created the United States of America. It is the reason we are here today.

— Bobby Jindal

title: Protesters Greet Candidates at G.O.P. Debate
content:
SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — Dozens of sign-waving protesters, many of them critical of Donald J. Trump, greeted the Republican candidates at the foot of the hill that leads to the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library.

<!-- more -->

Many of the protesters were Hispanic and held up signs denouncing Mr. Trump for his criticism of Mexican immigrants. "Dump Trump, Dump Hate," read one preprinted sign a few of them held. Others hoisted placards demanding citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

There were far more protesters than at the Republican presidential debates held here in the past two campaigns, an indication of Mr. Trump's impact and the rise of immigration as an issue. At Wednesday's event, they were kept behind barricades along a busy road, but, with oversized images of some of the candidates and one sign featuring a picture of Mr. Trump with a red slash through it, they were impossible to miss.
content_expanded:

title: Lindsey Graham and Rick Santorum Trade Quips
content:
Strom Thurmond had four kids after 67. If you’re not willing to do that, we better come up with a new legal immigration system.
— Lindsey Graham
I just want to say: I have seven kids, I’ve done my part.
— Rick Santorum
content_expanded:
Strom Thurmond had four kids after 67. If you’re not willing to do that, we better come up with a new legal immigration system.

— Lindsey Graham

I just want to say: I have seven kids, I’ve done my part.

— Rick Santorum

title: As Republican Debate Opens, Targets of Attacks Are Not Onstage
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003917163" crop="592" type="video" autostart="false"]

As the debate among the four trailing candidates began, it took only moments for the true targets to emerge — Hillary Rodham Clinton and Donald J. Trump — and neither was standing on the stage. 

<!-- more -->

Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana was quick to aim at both. He mocked Mrs. Clinton by noting that a "socialist" is gaining on her. "You can't make that up," he said. He then shifted to the dangers of the Republican Party nominating Mr. Trump. Either he will "implode in a general election," Mr. Jindal said, adding that if "God forbid" Mr. Trump won the White House, no one knows what he would do. 

The twin insults perfectly captured the sense of desperation among the struggling candidates. Their best hope to improve in the polls may be to prove their ability to tangle with those on top, during the Republican nomination fight and in a general election contest. 

In the opening minutes, Mr. Jindal made it clear that flinging insults is crucial to that strategy. In an earlier answer, he called Mr. Trump "a narcissist who only believes in himself," and ended his second answer with a simple declaration about the Republican front-runner: "He's not serious," Mr. Jindal said.
content_expanded:
Photo: Max Whittaker for The New York Times; Video: By CNN

Either he will “implode in a general election,” Mr. Jindal said, adding that if “God forbid” Mr. Trump won the White House, no one knows what he would do.

The twin insults perfectly captured the sense of desperation among the struggling candidates. Their best hope to improve in the polls may be to prove their ability to tangle with those on top, during the Republican nomination fight and in a general election contest.

In the opening minutes, Mr. Jindal made it clear that flinging insults is crucial to that strategy. In an earlier answer, he called Mr. Trump “a narcissist who only believes in himself,” and ended his second answer with a simple declaration about the Republican front-runner: “He’s not serious,” Mr. Jindal said.

title: Anderson Cooper to Moderate First Democratic Debate
content:
SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The first — and much anticipated — Democratic debate next month finally has a moderator: CNN's Anderson Cooper, who hosts the prime-time “Anderson Cooper 360” on the network.

CNN, which is hosting Wednesday night's second Republican debate, confirmed that Mr. Cooper would be hosting the first Democratic debate, which is scheduled for Oct. 13 in Las Vegas. 

Unlike in the Republican debate, where Jake Tapper is moderating two back-to-back debates — one "undercard" with the lower-polling candidates, and the prime-time show — Mr. Cooper will simply have one performance on which to focus. 

No word on any likely questions, but with a venue in Nevada, with its rapidly growing Hispanic population, expect immigration to come up.
content_expanded:
SIMI VALLEY, Calif. — The first — and much anticipated — Democratic debate next month finally has a moderator: CNN’s Anderson Cooper, who hosts the prime-time “Anderson Cooper 360” on the network.

CNN, which is hosting Wednesday night’s second Republican debate, confirmed that Mr. Cooper would be hosting the first Democratic debate, which is scheduled for Oct. 13 in Las Vegas.

Unlike in the Republican debate, where Jake Tapper is moderating two back-to-back debates — one “undercard” with the lower-polling candidates, and the prime-time show — Mr. Cooper will simply have one performance on which to focus.

No word on any likely questions, but with a venue in Nevada, with its rapidly growing Hispanic population, expect immigration to come up.

title: CNN to Start G.O.P. Debate an Hour Earlier, Making It 3 Hours
content: [nytmedia id="100000003916816" crop="592" type="image"] When Fox News shattered ratings records drawing nearly 24 million viewers to the first Republican debate last month, it set high expectations for CNN to match. And so far, CNN's strategy for boosting ratings seems to be: Debate, debate, debate. Not just in their plans Wednesday night, where they've said they will encourage raw, visceral candidate interaction, but also in their pre-debate coverage, which has included dispatches from the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, showing the candidates walking through the set or CNN talent describing the lecterns and microphones. And, perhaps most important, in the length of the main show itself. CNN announced that its prime-time debate would start an hour earlier, at 8 p.m. Eastern, meaning there will be three full hours devoted to the debate. Though that won't all be actual debate time — as of this weekend, a CNN executive said the questioning would probably being around 8:30 and end a bit before 11 — the three-hour window gives CNN additional time to potentially improve ratings. The so-called undercard debate, featuring four candidates who did not qualify for prime time, starts at 6 p.m. Between the two debates, CNN will also bring all of the candidates onstage for a "class picture" — the first time the 16 Republicans will all appear together. On Twitter, Donald J. Trump — never one to shy away from news media attention — seemed to quibble with CNN's approach. "Will be heading over to the debate soon," he wrote. "Can you believe @CNN is 'milking' it for almost 3 hours? Too long, too many people on stage!"
content_expanded:
When Fox News shattered ratings records drawing nearly 24 million viewers to the first Republican debate last month, it set high expectations for CNN to match.

And so far, CNN’s strategy for boosting ratings seems to be: Debate, debate, debate.

Not just in their plans Wednesday night, where they’ve said they will encourage raw, visceral candidate interaction, but also in their pre-debate coverage, which has included dispatches from the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, showing the candidates walking through the set or CNN talent describing the lecterns and microphones.

And, perhaps most important, in the length of the main show itself.

CNN announced that its prime-time debate would start an hour earlier, at 8 p.m. Eastern, meaning there will be three full hours devoted to the debate. Though that won’t all be actual debate time — as of this weekend, a CNN executive said the questioning would probably being around 8:30 and end a bit before 11 — the three-hour window gives CNN additional time to potentially improve ratings.

The so-called undercard debate, featuring four candidates who did not qualify for prime time, starts at 6 p.m.

Between the two debates, CNN will also bring all of the candidates onstage for a “class picture” — the first time the 16 Republicans will all appear together.

On Twitter, Donald J. Trump — never one to shy away from news media attention — seemed to quibble with CNN’s approach. “Will be heading over to the debate soon,” he wrote. “Can you believe @CNN is ‘milking’ it for almost 3 hours? Too long, too many people on stage!”

title: Obama Scolds Republicans for ‘Talking Down America’
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003916761" crop="592" type="image"]

While the White House says President Obama has no plans to watch tonight’s Republican presidential debate, he did weigh in with a harsh assessment of the candidates, charging that they were “talking down America.”

“In the echo chamber that is presidential politics, everything is dark and everything is terrible,” Mr. Obama said during remarks on the economy Wednesday at the Business Roundtable,  which includes dozens of chief executives from major corporations. “They don’t seem to offer any solutions to the disasters that they perceive, but they are quick to tell you who to blame.”

“I’m here to say that there’s nothing particularly patriotic or American about talking down America,” the president said.

While Mr. Obama did not mention him by name, the remarks seemed targeted at Donald J. Trump, the Republican front-runner in the polls whose campaign slogan, stitched on his trademark red cap, is “Make America Great Again.”

The dig came from a president who has himself been accused by Republicans of not believing in American greatness, a charge leveled when he traveled abroad during his first term in what some critics called his “apology tour.” It is also a central theme of a new book by former Vice President Dick Cheney, “Exceptional: Why the World Needs a Powerful America,” in which Mr. Cheney argues that Mr. Obama has weakened the position of the United States in the world. 

On Wednesday, the president dismissed what he called the “doom and gloom” emanating from the presidential campaign trail and Republicans in general.

“America’s winning right now. America’s great right now,” Mr. Obama said, quickly adding, “We can do even better.”

Later, Mr. Obama seemed unable to resist another veiled swipe at Mr. Trump, who argued during a Capitol Hill rally this month that the nuclear deal with Iran had been negotiated by "totally incompetent people," and who routinely suggests that the president has been outfoxed and outmaneuvered.

"I’m just going to go on a quick rant here for a second," Mr. Obama said in the middle of a discourse on the United States' relationship with China. "This whole notion that somehow we're getting out-competed, out-dealt, out-this, out-that -- we're losing -- nobody outside the United States understands what we're talking about."
content_expanded:

While Mr. Obama did not mention him by name, the remarks seemed targeted at Donald J. Trump, the Republican front-runner in the polls whose campaign slogan, stitched on his trademark red cap, is “Make America Great Again.”

The dig came from a president who has himself been accused by Republicans of not believing in American greatness, a charge leveled when he traveled abroad during his first term in what some critics called his “apology tour.” It is also a central theme of a new book by former Vice President Dick Cheney, “Exceptional: Why the World Needs a Powerful America,” in which Mr. Cheney argues that Mr. Obama has weakened the position of the United States in the world.

On Wednesday, the president dismissed what he called the “doom and gloom” emanating from the presidential campaign trail and Republicans in general.

Later, Mr. Obama seemed unable to resist another veiled swipe at Mr. Trump, who argued during a Capitol Hill rally this month that the nuclear deal with Iran had been negotiated by “totally incompetent people,” and who routinely suggests that the president has been outfoxed and outmaneuvered.

title: Bobby Jindal Says ‘11th Commandment’ Does Not Apply to Trump
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003916367" crop="592" type="image"]

For the four candidates in the Republican debate "undercard" tonight, one strategy to make sure that they are not entirely forgotten in the morning-after conversations and highlight reels is to go after Donald J. Trump with fresh zingers — though that could give rise to an odd situation in which contestants engage with an absent rival more than with the ones present.

Indeed, an aide to Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana said that the governor, one of four candidates consigned to the early forum, planned to use a good portion of his time on camera to press his case against Mr. Trump.

Mr. Jindal, who has previously called Mr. Trump a "carnival act," wants to convince primary voters that the party's front-runner in the polls right now is not a true conservative.

In a statement before the debate, Mr. Jindal said Ronald Reagan's "11th commandment" not to criticize fellow Republicans did not apply in Mr. Trump's case. 

"Instead of trying to convince people that Trump is not a conservative, I have told voters the truth — he is a narcissistic egomaniac who will waste the conservative movement's last, best chance to Make America Great Again, by gifting the White House to Hillary Clinton," Mr. Jindal said.

Another motive for Mr. Jindal (and others) to try punching up toward Mr. Trump is that CNN has promised that if a participant in the early debate says something "particularly sharp or interesting," a video clip may be played in the larger debate for candidates to respond to.

Mr. Jindal is so deep in the polls, though, that Mr. Trump has not bothered to counterattack him in the way he has other rivals.

It is hard to say, for Mr. Jindal, which may be worse: the venom of Mr. Trump's sting, or the sting of being ignored.
content_expanded:
